I would recommend a controller to play, but keyboard works well too. 												When the LEGO series burst onto the scene with LEGO Star Wars in 2005, it was an instant hit. The game's simple controls, fun humor, and family-friendly gameplay made it a classic among players and assured it a spot in the upper echelon of licensed games. However, as the LEGO series started branching out and extending its trademark influence across other properties, it seemed as if some of the spark had faded. The LEGO Indiana Jones games in particular were criticized for having numerous glitches and having a general lack of polish.When I started playing LEGO: Harry Potter, I had some serious concerns. However, it looks like Traveler's Tales has gotten back to doing what they do best with LEGO Harry Potter, and the love that they put into this title definitely shows.Right from the moment you start the game, the affection the developers have for the series as a whole is apparent. The opening cutscene features a mish-mash of humorous takes on the opening scenes from Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone mixed with a few nods to both the fans of the books as well as previous LEGO games. I won't spoil anything here, but it must be said that the cutscenes in LEGO Harry Potter are definitely on par with the best of the cutscenes from the LEGO: Star Wars series.The cutscenes definitely continue the series' trademark humor, and the gameplay follows suit by providing users with more of the same puzzle-platform style of gameplay that has been featured in previous LEGO titles. Although this sounds a little disparaging, it's actually quite a boon for the game in this instance. The LEGO fanbase is one that must have some repetitious elements, especially when you consider that many of the players are quite young. Having a repetitious format may become tiresome in a game series designed for adults, but with a franchise with fans with single-digit ages, being able to hop right in and know what to do is key for success.That's not to say, however, that there are no new elements in LEGO Harry Potter. Instead of a single action you can take with items in game, LEGO Harry Potter features more than ten special spells that you can use to achieve various effects in the game. These spells can be easily cycled through using the shoulder button, and add a new puzzle element to the game.Although there are quite a few spells (including the always-funny Ridikkulus spell), the one you are most likely to use in 90% of situations is Wingardium Leviosa. This levitation spell is the first spell you learn and will be used to move objects around and interact with switches. The Lumos spell is also used quite a bit, along with various graduated intervals of attack-style spells including Expecto Patronus and Incendio.And speaking of combat, there is a fair bit of magic-based fighting in LEGO Harry Potter. This is a change of pace from previous LEGO games, but it sits nicely with the overall tone of the game. The Harry Potter series of movies and books has always been well-known for its magical creatures and (at least in the beginning) fantastical battle sequences. Although boss battles generally do contain some amount of puzzling, you will be able to fire off magical spells from your wand fairly easily to overpower your opponent.LEGO Harry Potter does a great job of refreshing and updating the LEGO series for the Harry Potter universe, but unfortunately, there are several problems that remain. One of the problems that returns from other games is the camera. Though you may not notice it if you are playing co-op and staying close to your partner, if you are playing with an adventurous partner or with a bunch of AI-controlled characters, you'll notice the camera following the wrong character or zooming out to the point of near-unplayability.Another thing that you must know coming in is that the best way to experience LEGO Harry Potter is with a friend. Playing by yourself can be quite an exercise in frustration, and AI-controlled characters can be painfully difficult to deal with, especially when you need to get them to a certain platform or area so you can proceed. Sure, you can always use your Wingardium Leviosa spell to get them in the correct position, but this can become quite the chore and make the game feel more like Hogwarts' babysitting service than a real adventure.A final complaint I have with this title is with the game's hub system. While hubs in previous LEGO titles have been expansive with plenty to explore, the Diagon Alley hub feels almost overwhelming. I had to search for several minutes just to find the character-purchase shop, and it felt like a chore going through the different areas, waiting for loading screens, and then tracking down who I needed to get new wardrobe choices, extra spells, or watch cutscenes. Though this may sound like a small gripe, I really relished the overall simplicity of previous games, and the complicated nature of the hub world just took away from the game's overall immersion.Technically speaking, everything in Harry Potter maintains the status quo, which is a good thing. Cutscenes look polished, and in-game graphics maintain the signature brick-style that has become synonymous with the LEGO series. The only quibble I have with the game's visual styling (and it is a minor one) is that environments can get a little too busy at times and it can be hard to be precise with your targeting when you have dozens of interactive elements on screen. However, this only occurs in a handful of areas, and can usually be remedied by walking up to whatever element you want to interact with and targeting it directly (instead of just heading in the general direction and pressing a button.LEGO: Harry Potter Years 1-4 is certainly the best of the post-Star Wars LEGO games. The story material is handled wonderfully (though if you've never read the books or watched the movies, prepare to be lost), and the gameplay is a great mix of familiar devices and new elements. Although the inevitable follow-up to this title may take a darker turn, I look forward to experiencing it all the same.Recommended

Notes: Controller highly recommended!  This is my first LEGO PC game.  GINORMOUS spider warning!Options include fully-mappable controls, resolution from 800x600 to 1920x1080, and a variety of quality settings for graphics and effects.As someone who'd never played a LEGO PC game before, I found gameplay to be a bit confusing and overwhelming at first.  The key is to explore, interact with and/or destroy everything you possibly can, and collect every coin (aka stud) you see, as you'll need them for purchases later.There is no speech in the game - everything is communicated via tone of voice ("Uh?" "Uh!") and character actions.  The LEGO HP games are based upon the movies, from the Fat Lady trying to break a crystal glass with her voice to the movie soundtrack.  I have both listened to the whole series of audio books (Jim Dale is an AMAZING narrator!) and watched all of the movies, so I am pretty knowledgeable about the world of Harry Potter.  I'm really not sure that these games would be as enjoyable for someone who isn't familiar with the stories, and they are of course FULL of spoilers!There are six chapters per "year", for a total of 24 levels to play.  Once you finish a chapter, you can replay it by going to the glowing board in The Leaky Cauldron (your home base, so to speak), and choosing it from the list.  You will NEED to replay chapters in Free Play mode in order to get all of the collectibles, as you'll need alternate characters that you won't be able to unlock until later in the game.There is also all of Hogwarts, Diagon Alley, Nocturn Alley, and Gringotts to explore outside of the story levels.Cutscenes can be skipped once you've seen them the first time.Spells and Abilities:Your characters will learn a variety of spells as you progress, and though you can manually switch between spells, I recommend leaving it on "pink" (Wingardium Leviosa aka levitation) at all times.  First of all, your characters will automatically used the spell you need most of the time, and it's too easy to miss things that you need to interact with if you have any other spell selected.  Leaving it on pink will make a pink halo appear around anything you can use Leviosa on, which will save you a lot of frustration later.A lot of characters have their own special ability, so you'll need to switch between characters often.  A few examples:  Hagrid is very strong, Hermione and Ron have pets that can interact with the environment in their own way, Harry has the invisibility cloak, goblins have keys, dark wizards are the only ones who can interact with items that have red sparkles around them, Hermione can use the time-turner, sometimes you'll need to be a Hufflepuff, Ravenclaw, or Slytherin to get past certain blockades... (Hello polyjuice potion!)Collectibles:- 167 character tokens (you'll have to purchase the ability to use them once you find the tokens)- 200 gold bricks- 50 students in peril- True Wizard (collect a specified amount of studs in each story level, which will earn you an extra gold brick)- 20 red bricks (allows you to purchase abilities/bonuses.  Pause the game, select Extras, then turn on the ones you want to use)- 24 Hogwarts crests, each consisting of four pieces: Red (Gryffindor), Blue (Ravenclaw), Green (Slytherin), and Yellow (Hufflepuff)- Spells to purchase at Wiseacres Wizarding Supplies (love that one that makes the person you hit turn into a human slug)Besides being a completionist, there are several other reasons to be collecting gold bricks:- Build special items in the basement of The Leaky Cauldron - one for each "year"- Unlock vaults in Gringotts, which gives you access to challenge levels, which in turn earns you another gold brick- Unlock an extra level in Borgen & Burkes (have to have collected all 200 bricks!)The red bricks I mentioned above allow you to purchase some great abilities, such as stud multipliers, brick detectors, token detector, fall rescue (so helpful!), and more.  You can go to Wiseacres Wizarding Supplies and enter a cheat code to get these abilities if you haven't found the red brick/purchased it yet, but I personally did it all the hard way... I didn't even know how to turn the abilities on until after I finished the game. ;DAll in all, LEGO Harry Potter is a beautifully-done tribute to the world JK Rowling created, and Hogwarts was a true pleasure to explore.  There was a strong sense nostalgia with the familiar locations and the movies' music, but it was still fresh due to the way the stories needed to be adjusted to make the gameplay interesting.  I had no technical difficulties (unless you count the THREE items I cannot find to get my 100% completion, which is really a user-error), and I really had a lot of fun.  Absolutely recommended.

												LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1 - 4What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said? It's got that same LEGO charm and goofiness that we've all come to know and love since 2005's LEGO Star Wars: The Video Game. Parodying the first four Harry Potter movies (The Philosopher's Stone, The Chamber of Secrets, The Prisoner of Azkaban, and The Goblet of Fire), this game has the potential to bring new people into the Harry Potter fandom. It inspired me to watch the eight movies, and I must say that they're all wonderful. The puzzles in this game are clever, the satirical humor is an amazing thing to have considering how dark the movies get, and the idea of having the 'Dexter's Diner' and level select rooms as the Diagon Alley and Hogwarts Castle (respectively) overworlds are truly fantastic.But, I'm afraid I can't give this game a perfect score like I would for other titles in the series. LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1 - 4 falls just short due to one fatal flaw in the game: Game breaking glitches.In Year 3 Act 6, right near the beginning of the level, there are two switches that you need to hit to melt ice off a door to continue on. Hitting either of these crashes the game. But there is a workaround to it, thankfully. Just go into 2 player mode, place player 1 in a corner far away from a door, have player two hit the right switch, and have them drop out back to player 1. After waiting for a few minutes, do this again, but this time have player 2 take blind shots at the left switch, and then wait after you hit it. I know, it's convoluted and crazy, but it works. In the same level, there's a glass window that you need to break. The first time I tried to break it, the sound played but the entity in the map remained. This is fixed by a simple re-entering of the level, or restarting the game if you want to be sure. Just remember the glitch before that window.But in Year 4 Act 2....there's a huge problem. The third dragon you take care of, a blue one, is supposed to be raised up on a platform whenever you walk onto a certain spot on the walkway on his cage. Instead of working like he should, he instead falls right through the platform. As this is a glitch in the physics engine for the game, I kept trying again but had the same result. But one time the dragon went through the ceiling of his cage. And another time, he worked. BUT, the fireball that he shoots teleported as soon as it left his mouth, and hit the back left corner of the platform. I had heard that you, again, needed to go into two player mode to get this to work. The first time it almost did, but then he went through the ceiling again. Which is, admittedly, kinda funny. But the other two tries just had the same result as the first time I encountered this glitch. As of yet, I have not found a workaround or fix in the files to remedy this problem.Overall, I give this game an 8/10, and highly recommend it to any fan of Harry Potter, or the LEGO games in general. But, for the time being, I would also recommend that you get it in physical form just in case the above glitches are Steam exclusive. I will edit my score later on should there ever be a patch released for this game that fixes the above glitches.

												LEGO Harry Potter: Years 1-4 is yet another LEGO game. This time riding on the first four Harry Potter movies. Released in 2010, made by Traveller's Tales, published by Warner Bros. It also came out for Xbox 360, PS3, Wii, NDS, PSP and iOS.Out of ports the only notable ones are NDS, PSP and iOS ones. It's a different game, more like isometric exploration of small levels where you do quests for characters. While collecting studs.Technically, this PC version is known to be a pretty badly done. Actually, this game is full of glitches on any platforms. You can google out a whole list of them. It actually might be useful to check one out, to know what to avoid.Personally, I had no problems with this game. But I didn't try to 100% it anyway. I only once had trouble with making game recognise controller, so I had to restart PC. And it crashed once.But there are just way too many reposts of real nasty glitches. Some can't make it start without crash. Other experienced losing a save! And many also have game freezing in Year 3 on Dark Tower level when activating one of the gargoyles that shoot fire. I didn't had trouble, but I played this stage only once. But the solution seem to indiacate that it something to do with rendering dynamic light. You either activate it off-screen or change config file of a game. Just check on guides.As for gameplay itself, it's yet another Traveller's Tales lego game. It's like lego game, but with all stuff that lego sequels get. Be casual, have infinite lives, collect-a-thon, do simple puzzles. It's getting stale and writing Steam reviews on them is getting stale too.Actually, well, this time is different, because Harry Potter is the franchise I am familar with and love. Read books, you see. And then 50 years later I will be sitting with my kids and explain them how awesome it was. And then I will realize that everybody read books too and Warner is still making money with more Harry Potter stuff.Plot isn't all that changed. Lego figures still don't speak. So it's recommended to watch movies first, really. Well, okay, plot was changed a bit so there is always at least two characters to control at any time, so you can always have fun with a friend.And actually, I like this LEGO iteration. There are almost no annoying fights with respawning enemies which is a huge plus in these earlier LEGO games. It's more puzzle focused than that. I also actually laughed a few times. The world here is much more lively, combining levels and hub around pretty nice. You can even get another "collectable" - "Student in peril". Help somebody out of sticky situation and feel good about it. No more ledge jumping, more of spell-choosing and aiming. It also felt like I was restricted from less stuff in Story Mode than in previous LEGO games, you can get more stuff the first time around with what is given to you.Protip: To destroy the monster books, you have to come close and press Tag button for some reason.Eh. It's nice. For me this whole Lego franchise got stale, as I tried to beat it in chronological order and beat Star Wars, two Indiana and the first Batman. But for those who didn't play much of Lego games this one will be nice. Actually, looking at it again, it is good as part of franchise too, as I realize that I had less frustration due to Lego Harry Potter having less respawning enemies. But watch out for all the glitches!

												My review will be based in a few things:1 - I Love Hairy Petter and Hairy Petter games2 - I Finished 100% of the game3 - I've played with an Xbox 360 controller4 - I'm not a native english speaker5 - This is my first reviewLet's start õ/Like I said, I love Harry Potter and I kinda like Lego games... so this was very interesting.Graphics:Nothing special, but they have done a great job recreating the cenario7/10Cenario Immersion:Sometimes it feels empty, almost no interaction with the castle except for the parts that you must interact to continue the game. There is not that much places that you can go, but still made me feel disoriented and I've made myself a mental map to know where was i. Even knowing that there is not that much to go, they made it in a way that i almost didn't care, which is nice.7/10Story:They've cut a lot of the 4th year... the whole ball... NOT EVEN A CUTSCENE DDD:Well, frustrations aside, they've made some changes from the original movie(s) just to make it "comic". I know this supposed to be a kid's game, but Harry Potter story isn't something very... kids safe... but... well, ♥♥♥♥it. Like i was saying, those changes doesn't affect the story that much and some changes had to be made to save time and not to make the game too long, but all the other parts were quite accurate.8/10Gameplay:AI sometimes can ♥♥♥♥ you up, but is very well programed for the other parts, and if you play this game as it should be played (no exploits nor glitches) you'll have no problems with AI. Even in parts where two players need to separate in order to complete a puzzle.AI 7/10The controls can give you a hard time if you want to finish this game quickly... the spell selection is kinda of confusing and messy (Xbox 360 controller) but... you get usued to.Control 7/10The spell detection sucks... you want to cast a Leviosa on a purple thing and then you are levitating Ron. To kinda "fix" this, they've made a manual target. But still... even with the target on the purple thing, sometimes it doesn't recognizes the object's purple aura.Spell detection 3/10Character control is fine... not perfect due camera angles and some leviosa's sensitivity, but it does the job.Character control 6/10Action detection: i don't know what is worse, spell detection or action detection... when you want to put the skelleton arm in the cauldron, you have to be almost inside the ♥♥♥♥ing thing... when you want to use your pet two passes away from the cauldron, you get teleported to the ♥♥♥♥ing cauldron...Action detection 2/10Overall gameplay 7/10Sound:Can't tell a lot, but the soundtrack is like the one in the movie(s). BUT it doen't have a big collection, so you hear the same music in Hogwarts over and over and over and over again. I like the music from Harry Potter, but who isn't a fan and really pay attention to soundtrack is going to get bored really quick.Sound effects are ok, not much variation either.7/10Extras:This is where i've spend the most time playing. There are a lot of things to collect in Hogwarts and if you want to complete 100% or not, i really recommend getting at least all character tokens. It makes you explore the whole castle and see all the other parts that were really well done and with a lot of details. Some parts of the castle you wouldn't even know it exists because just playing Story Mode doesn't give you the complete hogwarts experience.There are some collectibles that are really a pain to find (Students in Peril) and if you want to get 100%, you have to play the game twice (one in story mode and one in free play).9/10Other things:A few glitch here and there, but nothing serious. EXCEPT for the save file. This is the worst type of save system that could exist. I've said that you have to complete the game twice to get 100%, well, i've completed 6 times because of the poor checkpoint system, only one save file that is easily corruptible, no cloud save, file location is "hidden" and you can't force a save... only when you get a token, get a golden brick, a red brick, save a student or finish a story sequence. I've got so frustrated the first time that i was 82% and then all the sudden, my save got currupted. I've waited another holiday season to play it again. If you are trying 100%, I recommend creating backup files every time you see the auto save icon.This is easy a 5h game or 22h 100% game.Overall:It's a nice casual game that makes you want to complete 100% and gets you addicted quite fast. Even with this save problem, the game is well done in general and i had a lot of fun playing it alone.I recommend this to a Lego games fan or a Harry Potter fan.7/10

Oh boy, the childhood memories come rushing back.  My review of this may be slightly nostalgia-biased, due to countless hours of playing this on my Wii, but I will try to be as honest as possible.     The gameplay is fantastic; it is a LEGO game after all.  The game has puzzles, some moderate action and is overall quite enjoyable.  The puzzles aren't anything too mind blowing, they're pretty standard for anyone who's played a LEGO game: Smash a couple things here, use a special ability there.  However, the controls do not support the mouse and will reset to defaults upon restarting the game, so I would highly reccomend the use of a gamepad; it makes life easier.      As far as graphics go the game is quite well optimized and looks pretty great; the screenshots on the store page do it absolutely no good.  With my current PC, (R9-280, 8GB of RAM and an FX-6300) I am getting a framerate of around 350 frames per second with all settings maxed at 1080p.  The game seems to compensate for its mediocre shading and texturing with some decent depth of field, bloom, and motion blur.  Some may argue that those effects are simply put in place to cover up bad graphics, however that's exactly what they do; The post processing effects cover up mediocre graphics, which is fine in my book.  The game looks great, and provides incredible performance.     Fun?  Absolutely.  It's a LEGO game for christ's sake!  There is little more fun than running around smashing everything in sight and flinging spells aimlessly around Hogwarts.  The perfect game for any Harry Potter fan who is a child at heart.  Aspect Score   Gameplay 7.5   Graphics 8   Fun 9.5 Overall Score: 8.3Warning:  go into your Windows playback device settings and change the default format to 24 bit @ 48000 Hz, the game will crash on startup otherwise.

Harry Potter : Years 1-4This review was last edited when I had completed level 2 (end of year 1)Short ReviewAn unspectacular game with decent co-op game play that is good fun to play with kidsLong ReviewJust to clearup a couple of points that confused me when I was looking to purchase this game for my son (aged 6) - the title "Years 1-4" refer to the years Harry was at Hogwarts, not the expected age of the player :)  and local coop means you only need one copy of the game as multiple players share a single computer using their own controller plugged into the one PC.This was the first lego game I played and if I'm honest I have to say I wouldn't play this game on my own. However, I purchased it so I could play a game with my eldest son and in that regard it has not disappointed as it really is great fun as a coop game.The game plays in 2D with depth and your view is from the side looking slightly down. You control one character at a time with various characters available depending on where you are. You can switch between characters to make use of the different abilities available to each character with the computer controlling the non-player controlled characters and basically just moving them along with you.The puzzles whilst not always logically solved (at least in my mind) are generally good fun, although a few are a bit tedious in that it seems to me its just a case of trying just about everything you can think of and the final solution simply has no logical reason why it should work behind it other than it does work. I also found some of the boss battles a bit tedious, e.g. final boss at end of level 2.As only a casual follower of the Harry Potter films the game seems to keep close enough to the storyline for me to relate it to the film.On the basis of playing this game I am purchasing other lego games as they come on sale with a view to playing those with my son too.ProsCoopThe split screen works well if the characters are separated in coop modeReasonably faithful to the film plotNice gentle humourConsAwkward user interfaceOccasionally the game seemed to lose connection with the controllers and I've not experienced this in other games but not played enough games with two controllers to be sure the problem is only with thsi gameYou have to complete a level to save the gameI found gauging where a character was depth wise on the screen a little difficultMarks Out Of 55) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted1) Not worth getting even if given away freeWhere I got the game fromI paid £2.08 on  Uplay [uplay.ubi.com]Platform Played OnIntel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, XBOX Controller For PC

												Let me start this off by saying that it has issues. A lot of issues. Seriously, what is it with LEGO Games and game breaking glitches? I was often blocked off from some parts of the levels because of glitches and had to restart the game. Also, the controls aren't optimized very well for the KB+M. There's no mouse support and they'll refer to your WASD keys as "Left Stick". That's how bad it is. Just use a controller.However, all the unpatched glitches aside, it's not a bad game. It has the spirit of every other LEGO game, which is going around and building stuff. It's a game about creativity, and they couldn't have chosen a better setting than Hogwarts to let people explore in. Keep in mind that this is heavily reflected in many of the "puzzles", too. The puzzles in this game aren't about testing your intuition. They're about innovation and creativity. Often when you are stuck on something that appears to be a puzzle, the answer is actually to BUILD something. It's not just about the LEGO aethetics, it's about the mindset. Looking at you, LEGO Marvel Super Heroes >.>As far as the game's CONTENT goes, Hogwarts is actually a fun place to explore in the game, but it's very small and confusing to navigate, which necessitates Nearly Headless Nick holding your hand throughout the entire game. I'd give the game a 7/10 because I enjoyed it and thought it was crafted together very well for what it was supposed to accomplish.

												It’s fun if you are into this niche.Story:It’s Harry Potter. Pretty much. The movies not the books.HOWEVER, some scenes are changed and made funnier/different for coop and general humor value (Cedric's death jesus ♥♥♥♥ing christ). Thing to note is that there are no voices so if you plan on following the story, you should know what happened. Otherwise, you’re going to be following a bunch of grunts. I really like the fact that the story is conveyed through grunts because it introduces a lot of slapstick and creative ways to explain the story. It requires genuine talent to write and I was impressed. It’s not hilarious but it has it’s charms. Obviously since it's a game, some scenes have more attention paid to them then the movies do and overall, I think they struck a good balance between what could be a level and couldn't. (except the boss fight with Malfoy... WTF?). The pace didn't grind to a halt too badly as there is a lot of material to cover anyways. Gameplay:If you’ve ever seen a lego game, it’s another one. You walk around, collect studs, do minor puzzles, and collect a million other things. As the years progress, you learn new spells which unlock different parts of the castle. I really liked this feature as each year had new areas to explore. However, the actual spell casting isn’t the best as switching between them and the targeting systems are super slow. So if you want to shoot, collect studs, and switch spells to lift something, it will take an unnecessarily long amount of time. Also, the core gameplay really starts to get boring after a while. You naturally explore the world which is fun but when you end up just walking in, shoot everything, and cast spells on specific items in each room, it gets repetitive. The character variety is pretty good with a lot of people that you can also unlock but most people have the same spells so there really isn’t any point. Overall, the gameplay is fun if you’re into Lego games but can get stale pretty fast.Graphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)The game doesn’t look amazing but not bad either. It’s pretty respectable for a 2010 game. The game seems to be stuck at 60 but I was constantly in the 200s so I’m good. The game did crash a bunch with it stabilizing a lot after a few restarts but very annoying.Final Thoughts:Lego games are Lego games. They are fun if you’re into collecting or something like that. This one is interesting because it’s not really aiming at kids. You first need to watch all of Harry Potter (deaths and all) and enjoy building lego which is what older fans usually like. So a kids game? Yes (because it's super toned down) and no (due to the knowledge you need to know going into the game). Ovearll, I thought it was not bad. Try it out on sale and see if you like the gameplay. Can get slow at times but it has its charm. UNLESS YOU GO FOR THE 100%. GOOD LUCK WITH THAT ♥♥♥♥

												I played this game for the first time in 2010 on the Nintendo Wii, and I saw this on sale for £2.49, so I bought it for PC seeing as I sold my Wii. STORY:The game goes through Harry Potter's first four years at Hogwarts (Philosopher's Stone/Sorcerer's Stone, Chamber of Secrets, Prisoner of Azkaban and Goblet of Fire). There are 6 levels in each year, along with some mucking about around the Hogwarts free-roam. Unfortunately, each story feels shorter than the last, seeing as there is a big difference between the amount of play in Year 1 and the amount of play in Year 4. Also, Goblet of Fire doesn't really feel like it fits in, seeing as it's about 2 hours of gameplay right at the end.GAMEPLAY: As you go on your journey, you'll unlock a full range of spells:ExpelliarmusRiddikulusExpecto PatronumLumos/Lumos SolemWingardium LeviosaImmobulusReductoPlus the ability to summon a pet, turn into an Animagus or use a magical item. The levels can be quite short, and you generally just use the spells to solve puzzles and, often in Year 4, defeat enemies.GRAPHICSThe graphics are OK, but Years 5-7 has the upper hand.FREE ROAMYou can explore all areas of Hogwarts Castle eventually (you unlock most of the areas in Year 1, a few in Year 2, a few in Year 3 and a few in Year 4. Plenty of stuff to keep you busy, like saving Students in Peril and hunting for new characters.CONCLUSIONI may have said some bad points of this game, but it's still a nice little package of Harry Potter magic. 1) Essential Purchase2)Recommended PurchaseRecommended during a sale4)Not recommended unless heavily discounted5)Not recommended even for hardcore Steam gamers

												This game was ported to PC with all the finesse of a rampaging hippopotamus conduting open heart surgery. The controls are a mess at times (two characters to control at the same time on the keyboard, needing to work together at times, one using WASD and one the arrow keys), none of the buttons are intuitive save basic movement, and I don't recall ever being told how to jump (it's U, or Num. 5, if you want to know). It is a console game first and foremost and it shows; there's a reason developers usually make one version of a game for the console and another for the PC. It took me most of Year 1 to get intuitive with the game controls, and I'm still not entirely sure.It's a testament to the charming nature of this game that I'm willing to put up with all of the above. The game makes gentle fun of the movies, keeping all the good parts in and playing down the tension to create what is ultimately an adorable, feelgood game I can get lost in for hours.The game boasts the film score as a soundtrack, which adds to the magic; you can never really die in any way that detriments you; you can run around Hogwarts to your heart's content in what might be the biggest sim of the castle I've encountered; there are multiple sidequests to keep you amused; and you can never really get stuck, because at least 60% of the gameplay is good old fashioned smashing things and rebuilding them with magic. If you're looking for a serious, challenging game, then LEGO HP is not for you. If you're looking for a fun game in which you can mess around, smash things, collect coins and generally regress to kindergarten, then I definitely recommend. I would recommend playing with a controller if you can, though, as that seems to help others.
